Array Class

The Array class is a class for handling arrays.

By creating an object of this class, you can treat it like an array using subscripts specified by the indirect member selection operator. Subscripts are integers. 0 represents the first element, and 1 represents the next element. If a negative integer is specified, it is treated as being specified from the end of the array (-1 represents the last element).

Example:
    var a = new Array();
    var i;
    for(i=0;i<100;i++) a[i]=i;

There is no need to declare the size of the array. The size is automatically expanded up to the size of the specified subscript, and elements to which no value has been assigned are initialized to void.

Also, there is a count property, which represents the size of the array. You can also change the size of the array by assigning a value to the count property.

In-expression Array

Using [ ], you can describe an Array class object on the spot within an expression. In [ ], enumerate expressions that will be the initial elements, separated by commas. For example, if you write
    var ar = ["a", "b", "c"];, a reference to an Array class object containing the elements "a" "b" "c" will be assigned to ar.

count

The count property represents the size of the array.

load

The load method reads an array from a file.

Syntax : load(<filename>, <mode=''>)
Reads an array from a text file. Each line of the file text enters each element, and finally, the count property will be the same as the number of lines in the file.
For the mode, specify the mode string when reading the file. This depends on the environment where TJS is running. Specifying a decimal offset following "o" will start reading from that byte position in the file.
Depending on the environment where TJS is running, this method and the save and saveStruct methods may not be available.
The load method returns this Array class object itself.

save

The save method writes the array to a file.

Syntax : save(<filename>, <mode=''>)
Writes the array to a file. Each member is output line by line, but references to objects, classes, functions, etc., will be blank lines.
For the mode, specify the mode string when writing the file. This depends on the environment where TJS is running, but in the case of Kirikiri, specifying "c" applies simple encryption to the file (it can be read directly with the load method). Specifying "z" allows saving the file compressed (cannot be used with "c"; this also can be read directly with the load method). Specifying a decimal offset following "o" will write from that byte position in the file. Specifying "b" saves in binary format (cannot be used with other mode specifications; this also can be read directly with the load method).
The save method returns this Array class object itself.

split

The split method splits a string.

Syntax : split(<pattern/delimiter set>, <string>, <(reserved)>, <ignore empty elements=false>)
Initializes the array and copies the string split by a pattern or delimiter set into this array.
Specify the pattern or delimiter set in the first argument.
The pattern must be a regular expression object.
In the delimiter set, specify the characters to be used as delimiters. By specifying a string, you can specify multiple delimiter characters.
The third argument is reserved for future versions.
For "ignore empty elements", specify true if you do not want to copy elements to the array in the case of empty elements (for example, ,,,,, when using a comma as a delimiter).
Please note the order of the arguments.

join

The join method joins the array into a single string.

Syntax : join(<delimiter>, <(reserved)>, <ignore empty elements=false>)
Joins each element of the array with a delimiter and returns the joined string.
If "ignore empty elements" is true, void values in the elements are ignored.

Example:
    var ar = [ "a", "b", void, "d" ];
    var s1 = ar.join(","); // s1 is assigned "a,b,,d"
    var s2 = ar.join(",",,true); // s2 is assigned "a,b,d"

reverse

The reverse method reverses the order of the array elements.

Syntax : reverse()

sort

The sort method sorts the array.

Syntax : sort(<sort order='+'>, <perform stable sort=false>)
The sort order is one of the following strings. In ascending order, elements are rearranged from smallest to largest, and descending order is the opposite. If omitted, it is assumed that '+' was specified.

"+"  : Ascending (comparison with normal < operator)
"-"  : Descending
"0"  : Ascending by number ( 10,2,1 is rearranged to 1,2,10 )
"9"  : Descending by number
"a"  : Ascending by string ( "a","c","b" is rearranged to "a","b","c" )
"z"  : Descending by string
A function can be specified instead of a sort order character. The function has two arguments. Specify a function that returns true when the first argument should come before the second argument (Note that the meaning of the return value is different from the function passed to JavaScript's sort method).

The second argument specifies whether to perform a stable sort. If omitted, it is assumed that false was specified, and an unstable sort is performed. In a stable sort, the order of array elements with the same rank remains the same after sorting. In the case of an unstable sort, there is no guarantee that the order of array elements with the same rank will be the same after sorting.

Example:
    var array = [ 0, 1, 2, 10, 12, 14, 4, 6, 2 ];
    array.sort();
        // ↑ After method execution, array becomes [0, 1, 2, 2, 4, 6, 10, 12, 14]
    array.sort('-');
        // ↑ After method execution, array becomes [14, 12, 10, 6, 4, 2, 2, 1, 0]
    array.sort('a');
        // ↑ After method execution, array becomes [0, 1, 10, 12, 14, 2, 2, 4, 6]

    var array = [ "hoge", "foo" , "bar", "baz" ];
    array.sort();
        // ↑ After method execution, array becomes ["bar", "baz", "foo", "hoge"]

    var array = [ "abcd", "abc", "ab", "a" , "b", "c" ];
    array.sort(function(a,b) { return a< b; } );
        // ↑ Same meaning as specifying '+'

    var array = [ "abcd", "abc", "ab", "a" , "b", "c" ];
    array.sort(function(a,b) { return a.length < b.length; } );
        // ↑ Order of shortest string length
        // (There is no guarantee that "a" "b" "c" with the same length
        // will be in the order "a" "b" "c" after sorting)

    var array = [ "abcd", "abc", "ab", "a" , "b", "c" ];
    array.sort(function(a,b) { return a.length < b.length; }, true );
        // ↑ Order of shortest string length
        // (Elements "a" "b" "c" with the same length will be in this order after sorting)

saveStruct

saveStruct outputs structured data to a file.

Syntax : saveStruct(<filename>, <mode=''>)
The saveStruct method outputs the state of the elements to a file in a restorable state.
Each element can include strings, real numbers, octet sequences, and integers. Also, if there is an object in an element, its contents will also be output to the file only if it is an Array class or Dictionary class object. For other elements, void is output.
For example,

Example:
    ([ 1, 2, 3, [4, 5], %[ a : 1, b : 2 ], "String" ]).saveStruct("out.txt");
then
(const) [
    1,
    2,
    3,
    (const) [
        4,
        5
    ],
    (const) %[
        "a" => 1,
        "b" => 2
    ],
    "String"
]
Content like the following is output. By evaluating this entire file as a single expression, you can restore the same structure as when it was saved.
Here, (const) indicates that the contents of [ ] or %[ ] only contain constant terms. When the compiler finds this (const), it can read the following in-expression dictionary array or in-expression array highly efficiently, assuming that the contents only consist of constant terms.
The saveStruct method returns this Array class object itself.

assign

The assign method copies an array.

Syntax : assign(<source array>)
Copies the contents of the other array specified in the argument exactly.

If a dictionary array (Dictionary class object) is specified as the source array, it becomes an array where each member of that dictionary array appears alternately in the order of name and value. The order of members is undefined.

assignStruct

The assignStruct method copies an array along with its structure.

Syntax : assignStruct(<source array>)
Copies the contents of the other array specified in the argument exactly.
Unlike the assign method, if a member is an array or a dictionary array, its contents are also copied recursively (in the case of the assign method, only the reference is copied).

clear

The clear method deletes all elements of the array.

erase

The erase method deletes the element at the specified subscript.

Syntax : erase(<subscript>)
Deletes the subscript at the specified position. Elements after the subscript are shifted forward one by one and packed. An exception occurs if the subscript is out of range.

remove

The remove method deletes elements that have the same value as the specified value.

Syntax : remove(<value>, <whether to delete all=true>)
Compares the specified value with each element for identity (operation of the === operator) and deletes the matching elements.
If "whether to delete all" is false, only the first element found is deleted. Otherwise, all elements found are deleted.

insert

The insert method inserts the specified value at the specified position.

Syntax : insert(<position>, <value>)
Inserts the element indicated by the value at the subscript position indicated by the position. Elements after the position are shifted back one by one.

add

The add method adds the specified value to the end of the array.

Syntax : add(<value>)
Adds the element indicated by the value to the end of the array.
This method returns the position where the value was added.

find

The find method returns the subscript where the specified value first appears.

Syntax : find(<value>, <search start position=0>)
Looks for the specified value starting from the subscript of the search start position and returns the first subscript found. Returns -1 if the specified value is not found.
Identity comparison (operation of the === operator) is used for comparison.

push

The push method adds the specified elements to the end of the array.
Unlike the add method, this method returns the size of the array after addition. Also, if multiple arguments are specified, all arguments are added in order.

Syntax : push(<value>, ...)

pop

The push method pops one element from the end of the array and returns it. The popped element is deleted from the array (the size of the array decreases by one).
This method returns the popped element. If there are no elements, it returns void.

Syntax : pop()

unshift

The unshift method adds elements to the beginning of the array. If multiple elements are specified, they can be added to the beginning. In this case, for example, if passed in the order a, b, c, the elements at the beginning of the array will be in the order a, b, c.
This method returns the size of the array after addition.

Syntax : unshift(<value>, ...)

shift

The shift method removes one element from the beginning of the array and returns it. The removed element is deleted from the array (the size of the array decreases by one).
This method returns the removed element. If there are no elements, it returns void.

Syntax : shift()

pack

The pack method converts the array elements into binary (Octet) according to the string specified in the argument and returns it.
The specified string is called a template.
The template is a sequence of type specification characters and their lengths. When * is specified as the length, it represents all remaining lengths. If the length is omitted, it is treated as 1.

Syntax : pack(template string)
The following characters can be used in the template string.
a : ASCII string (null-padded)
A : ASCII string (space-padded)
b : bit string (low-to-high order)
B : bit string (high-to-low order)
c : signed 1-byte integer (-128 to 127)
C : unsigned 1-byte integer (0 to 255)
d : double-precision floating-point value
f : single-precision floating-point value
h : hexadecimal string (low nybble first)
H : hexadecimal string (high nybble first)
i : signed int (usually 4 bytes)
I : unsigned int (usually 4 bytes)
l : signed long (usually 4 bytes)
L : unsigned long (usually 4 bytes)
n : unsigned short (network byte order)
N : unsigned long (network byte order)
s : signed short (usually 2 bytes)
S : unsigned short (usually 2 bytes)
v : unsigned short (little-endian)
V : unsigned long (little-endian)
x : null character
X : back up one byte
@ : null-fill to absolute position
m : Base64 decode

Example:
    var oct = array.pack("a4i2");
In this example, the string of array element 0 is output as 4 characters of char type, and if it is less than 4 characters, \0 is added.
Then elements 1 to 2 are added as signed 4-byte integers.
In other words, it is output as a binary sequence of char * 2 + int * 4.
